awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Control of invasive ants using an environmentally friendly bait approach
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of an eco-friendly bait for the control of invasive ants. Commercial toxic baits are currently the most efficient way to control invasive ants, but these baits negatively impact native biodiversity due to their lack of specificity. This, in turn, facilitates quick recolonization by invasive ants because no competitors are left to limit their spread. In addition, commercially available baits are incompatible with wet or sunny meteorological conditions as these events deactivate the bait’s active ingredient, and most commercial baits are attractive to ants mainly in spring and summer. The proposed technology provides a solution to these issues by delivering an ant bait formulation and delivery system that is 1) protected from moisture and sun, 2) attractive year-round, and 3) specifically targets invasive and pest ant populations. The proposed technology may allow pest-control companies to service parks and yards at any time of the day or year, yard owners to reduce the amount of insecticide applications per year, and ecosystems to recover through the recolonization of native invertebrate populations.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a formulation for an eco-friendly ant bait and a system to deliver it. The attractiveness of the bait was improved by the characterization of the key macronutrients required by Red Imported Fire Ants (Solenopsis invicta, hereafter RIFA) at different times of the year. Various proteins, lipids, and carbohydrates were tested, alone or in combination to create a bait that is highly attractive to RIFA populations in field conditions. The selected formulation combines the macronutrients that are the most important to the ants during each season, which ensures the attractiveness of the bait remains high at any time during the year. Unlike currently available products, this bait is not broadcasted over the infested area but is placed at the bottom of an opened, small, and biodegradable vial. The delivery of the bait into vials constrains foraging ants to compete for the access to the bait, passively selecting for the most abundant and competitive species: invasive ants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The development of our ant bait was initially only aimed at the publication of a patent. However, as soon as the patent became available online, a large agrichemical company contacted us about a collaboration to translate our IP into a marketable product. Two alternative options were available: (1) Complete a series of quality tests on our bait with the goal of licensing the IP, or (2) create a start-up company to start the commercialization of the bait on our own. Because of the performance of our bait in the lab, we entered the I-corps program with the confidence that it would find a broad customer base. The regional program gave us a first glance at the structure of our customer base, with two major segments: pest control companies and individual garden dwellers. We then believed that our product would be commercialized faster through pest-control companies and prepared the national program by contacting pest-control companies and IP owners who went through the process of licensing.

 

The combination of classes and interviews of the national program provided us with the methodology to investigate the needs of our customer segments. It also allowed us to understand the regulations associated with the commercialization of insecticidal products. During this first part of the program, we realized that pest-control companies seemed were generally happy with the currently available products, and the dissatisfaction from their customers was very low. On the other hand, individual backyard dwellers were often more dissatisfied with available products, and we identified the hobby vegetable gardeners to be the most strongly affected by the invasive ants. People from this customer segment were in fact generally trying to keep insecticides out of their vegetable patch and regularly in direct contact with the ants that like nesting in garden boxes. We thus made a pivot from pest-control companies to a much smaller but much more promising beach front market constituted by the hobby vegetable gardeners.

 

The funding granted by the I-corps program allowed us to go out to meet the representatives from distributor companies to ask them about volumes and costs, technical service managers from manufacturers to discuss partnerships, small and large retailers to ask about their criterions for including a new product on their shelves, R&D researchers, and innovation managers from large agrichemical companies. The key learning acquired during our meetings was that larger agrichemical companies were less interested in the improvement of existing products than in the development of totally new systems of pest control. Our baiting solution, despite being novel and an improvement compared to the available baits, was perceived as being similar to existing products. A second key learning outcome was that for large companies ensuring the reliability of the supply chain for the manufacture of the product is essential. Our bait, that uses a mixture of two vegetable oils, was viewed as being too complicated because current baits used only a single oil. To illustrate this issue, we were told that the disruption of oil supplies due to the war in Ukraine was costing millions of dollars to the company to find new suppliers and go through the EPA approval process again, and this is for soybean oil only.From this meeting, we started doing more lab research to identify a single oil that could be as attractive as our oil mixture and adapt our product to the realities of the market. We also looked for counselling about EPA regulations and the strategies to adopt in case of such a disruption in the supply chain. We met with a former member of the EPA who now works in consulting for dealing with that type of issue.

 

This series of meetings helped us realize that larger companies were unlikely to go forward with our bait formulation. We are now pivoting towards developing a start-up focused on our archetype customer of hobby gardener. Our lab research also identified an alternative oil as a very attractive single oil. This oil is produced locally and is an excellent candidate for our bait as we work to create a beachfront market from environmentally conscious gardeners.

 


Last Modified: 03/04/2024
Modified by: Spencer T Behmer
